I'm going to take this one step at a time, and edit this post a few times, putting in more points/other stuff or w/e each time. The first part are my points; the second is the evidence that the Bible is a reliable historical record.

point #0" Uh, "i.e." means "in other words" and "e.g." means "for example". I gotta try to compact my stuff.

Point #1: nobody can prove that God does not exist; i.e., the possibility that God exists is always there. This is God we're speculating about--something supernatural--obviously he could hide from us if he wanted to and so we'd have no way of detecting him--we'd have to know everything, which we don't, to prove he doesn't exist.

Point #2: if God exists, he could reveal himself to us in someway. How might he reveal himself to us and show he's all powerfer/supernatural/God? The first thing that comes to my mind is...miracles--the supernatural itself. But many scholars and others rule that out from the get go, and thus are flawed. So the point is miracles could happen since God could exist, so don't rule out the supernatural.

Point #3: Whichever religion, if any, has the most/greatest evidence for it, (that is, that God did reveal himself there) it is the most reasonable to believe.

it gets more technical here, since I define some things. you can skip it if u want; it kinda deals with if what we see is really real or w/e, and also defines facts, since we may not know for sure.

Point #4: Some things cannot be proven/known to be absolutely true with no possibility of otherwise, and some things can. E.g., you see your computer screen in front of you, so you know it's there; you've proven it to yourself with certainty. Science is all about what we can measure and see, as far as I know, and so can prove things, but even the laws of science are only good until we find more information that augments them or even does away with them; it has happened before. Why? Because we don't know everything. The thing is, it is still reasonable to act on things we don't know 1000000%. We use technology, so we believe in science/logic right? This is not unreasonable; Though there is always the possibility that something is not what we think, evidence for many things exists.
-Yes, this means I can't prove that God exists, as in completely prove/know with no possibility of being wrong. (I corrected myself below on this.) But the argument does not end here because, as point #2 said, if God could exist, he could show us evidence of him/reveal himself. I know of such evidence, which I am going to put in here eventually lol, and so I believe and put my faith in it being true.

point #5: When I say "facts" i don't necesarily mean what we know absolutely for sure, just what we reasonably know. For example, it is a fact that the Earth is a sphere (or very very close to one if u wanna get that technical), but do we know it certainly? Have you personally proved that and know it's true? Science has proven it; some things we can know for sure, like I was saying in point #4, but if you haven't proven it for yourself, there's still the possibility. My point is it's still reasonable to believe in things you don't know for certain, such as this example. You do it all the time. I trust (most) of what my friends tell me; though I haven't gone out and verified it, it's still reasonable to do under normal circumstances.

point #6: Um, some1's proly thinking how they can trust an opinionated source. Well, everyone is opinionated. If you don't believe the Bible, you are opinionated, and likewise if you do. What you can't trust is the prejudiced/biased source (I am still a little unclear on those terms). The source I have is about facts and logic, which is what we have to stick to.
